Author: smasma
Review:
‚òÜÔΩû„ÄéManshuin Monzeki„ÄèÔΩû‚òÜ

Manshu-in, a Buddhist temple located in Ichijoji, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a monzeki temple also known as Takenouchi Monzeki.
Along with Shoren-in Temple, Sanzen-in Temple, Myoho-in Temple, and Bishamondo Monzeki Temple, it is considered one of the Five Monzeki Temples in Tendai.
"Manshu" means "medicine" and "love music" in Sanskrit.
The character for special is a little different, but it seems to be derived from `` Manjushage '', which is a cluster amaryllis.
Manjushage is also known as the "heavenly flower".
It seems that it is derived from the Buddhist scripture, "As a good omen, red flowers will fall from the sky."
The Karesansui garden in front of the Daishoin of Manshuin Temple has been designated as a national scenic spot.
The pebbles spread all over express the flow of water, and Tsurushima and Kameshima are placed in it.
This season, the green foliage was vivid, but as autumn deepens, the foliage turns vermilion and becomes a wonderfully burning garden. I think it would be nice to take a slow look from the study room. If you go further from the Shoshoin, you will reach the ‚ÄúKaminodokoro‚Äù, which is currently open to the public.

On the way to follow the viewing route, you will see the wooden statues of Gansan Daishi, an important cultural property.
It is also known as the ‚Äúoriginator of omikuji‚Äù in Japan.
Finally, there is the ghost üëª hanging scroll.
We, who didn't know anything about such things, were surprised to see ghost paintingsüëªüëÄüí¶.
There were two hanging scrolls.

Review:
From Shisen-do and Enko-ji Temple to Manshu-in Temple at the end of a luxurious walk...

It is also said to be a small Katsura Imperial Villa, which is a monzeki temple. I see, so this is the dignity of the nobility and the royal family, even though it's simple.

First of all, the garden, which is said to be Kobori Enshu's favorite, and the dry landscape garden where Tsurushima and Kameshima are arranged in white sand representing water, are definitely included in the 30 best gardens.

After enjoying the garden, we will go on a tour of valuable cultural assets in the study room. Kano Eitoku's tiger painting, this Kokin Wakashu, which is a copy of a national treasure, and the wooden statue of Gansan Daishi, the originator of omikuji.

Author: Á•ûÊà∏Êò¥
Review: Shugakuin-michi bus stop is within walking distance. Together with Sanzen-in Temple, Shoren-in Temple, Myoho-in Temple, and Bishamon-do Temple, it is one of the Tendai sect's Five Monzeki Temples. . It is also called the "Small Katsura Imperial Villa" because the Cloistered Imperial Prince Ryosho was conscious of the beauty of the Katsura Imperial Villa that his father built, including the building, garden, shelves, transoms, and metal fittings. In fact, I visited the Katsura Imperial Villa the day after I visited here, and I thought it was very similar. In addition to the important cultural property designated Kuri, Tiger's Room, Daishoin, Koshoin, Enshu's favorite dry landscape garden, Kano school partition paintings and fusuma paintings, tea room Hassoken, owl's washbasin, etc. The highlight is the temple treasure designated as a national treasure, and this yellow fudo, which is counted as one of the three fudos together with Manshuin Kokin Wakashu, Myooin's red fudo, and Shorenin's blue fudo, is truly powerful and beautiful. By all means, please go out according to the beautiful autumn leaves. Also, at the end of the visit, there is a hanging scroll of a powerful ghost, so please prepare yourself mentally. Photography is prohibited inside the building. Free parking available.

Author: NU Chan
Review:
Is it called a small Katsura Imperial Villa?
Monzeki temple! I see, I see, this is the "class" that was favored by the imperial family and aristocrats, and the Sukiya-style shoin-zukuri and the elegant garden make me feel something called class even if I don't want to. Since I came in early May, I was able to admire the Kirishima azaleas. Tsubaki and the four seasons
It is easy to imagine that the plum blossoms, the autumn leaves are still outstanding. It is a temple of the Tendai sect that originated from the first monastery built by Saicho on Mt. It is a temple where children are the head of the temple for generations, and this temple started in the 4th year of the Ming Dynasty (1495) when the prince of the Fushiminomiya family, the high priest, acquired it. Since Korekokushi, the first monk of the temple, was from the Sugawara family, it has a deep relationship with Kitano Tenmangu Shrine, which enshrines Sugawara no Michizane as a deity. After several relocations, it was moved to its current location in 1656, in the early Edo period, by Cloistered Imperial Prince Ryoichi, who served as Tendai (the highest rank of the Tendai sect). At his father's palace, he excels in landscaping the tea ceremony, and beauty can be seen everywhere in the building and the garden, such as the metal fittings of the Daishoin Koshoin (both important cultural properties). It is enshrined, and there are eight tea houses (important cultural properties) to the north of Shoshoin. Currently entrusted to the Kyoto National Museum

Author: „Åü„Åë„Åª„Åå„Çâ
Review:
I got off at Ichijoji Station on the Eizan Electric Railway and used Google Maps to reach Manshuin Monzeki.

This temple seems to have a very close relationship with the imperial family. Here and there are pictures of the current retired emperor visiting here with the empress when he was still emperor. According to Wikipedia, "monzeki" means "a specific temple where the imperial family or court nobles serve as chief priests."

It was a tough place to take pictures. No inside the building, no outside garden from inside the building, no outside garden from the red carpet on the porch. So I took a picture of the garden as the main one.

Also, I couldn't go out of the building (garden), and when I looked at the pamphlet, there were important cultural properties such as the Kuri, Daishoin, and Koshoin, but I was disappointed that I couldn't take pictures. I was only able to take pictures of the imperial envoy gate (no entry) and the side gate from outside the premises.

This time we came during the season of green maple leaves, but you will surely be able to see the colorful garden during the fall foliage season.
(Visit: 2022-05-06)

Author: k n
Review: It was the end of jeans, but it wasn't so crowded in the morning. The blizzard of autumn leaves falling in the wind blowing in the garden created an autumn atmosphere.

Author: Kenji Shimamoto
Review:
On the day of the tour, we moved from our hotel in Shijo Kawaramachi to the vicinity of Enkoji Temple by subway and bus.
I applied for a special visit to the Hassoken tea room. A monk will guide you through the Hassoken tea room for about 15 minutes.
This is one of the three Kyoto seats, and the other two seats are Nanzenji/Konchiin Hassodo and Daitokuji/Koryan Bosenseki.
If you are interested in the tea room, please apply. You will enter from the Important Cultural Property Kuri (the kitchen of the temple), pass through the Tiger Room, the Daishoin, and the Shoshoin, and be guided to the Hassoken tea room. Originally, the entrance was from the garden, and there is a shelf for placing swords at the entrance.
The shelf can also be seen from the public viewing area if the location is known.
The garden designated as a scenic garden is also wonderful. There are Tsurushima and Kameshima in the dry landscape garden, and I would like to introduce them in more detail.
I went there during the autumn leaves season, so I could see the autumn leaves in the surrounding area and the garden, and I could see many paintings of the Kano school in the room.

Author: MAKI ISHIKAWA
Review:
About 15 minutes on foot from Enkoji Temple.
It was quiet and relaxing with a view of the garden. The sunset was beautiful too.

Author: „ÅÇ„Å®„Çä
Review:
I visited to see autumn leaves on November 18, 2010.

The autumn leaves were beautiful around the stone monument that guides you to "Manshuin", "Manshuin Tenmangu", the imperial envoy gate, and the approach to the entrance before the reception.
These were before the admission reception, so I was able to visit them for free.

After entering the building, we especially recommend the tiger paintings in the "Tiger Room".
The tiger walking triumphantly with the pudding and the buttocks out was very cute.
In addition, the Mt. Fuji-shaped nail cover and the chrysanthemum transom in the "Fuji-no-ma" were wonderful because they felt playful.

The garden was also in autumn leaves, and I was able to see the scenery that can only be seen at this time of year.

Author: Â±±Áî∞‰πÖÁî∑
Review:
Visited in Spring 2022.
Manshu-in Monzeki is one of the five temples of the Tendai sect, and was originally built by Saicho.

This temple has a strong connection with Junichiro Tanizaki, a great writer, and there is a temple bell donated by Mr. Junichiro, which is said to be used during memorial services.
Born in Tokyo, he was fascinated by Kyoto and moved there for seven years.

When I visited this time, it was just the season of young leaves, so I was able to see the beautiful green.
In addition, it overlapped with the blooming season of azaleas, and I was able to see the wonderful contrast of green and bright red.

Also, on the way back, you can also appreciate the ghost painting of the example.

If you are interested, you can check it out online for reference!

Of course, the garden is designated as a place of scenic beauty and is beautiful.
